author: By Daniel E. Slotnik, Adeel Hassan and Bryan Pietsch
title: Texas governor will bar local governments from requiring masks.
description: Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, issued an executive order on Tuesday that will prohibit cities and counties from enforcing mask mandates.
content: Most government authorities in Texas will soon be prohibited from requiring people to wear masks, Gov. Greg Abbott announced on Tuesday, days after federal health officials announced new guidance that encourages people who have been completely vaccinated to forego masks in most situations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Reeve
title: Don’t Just Buy Any Bath Towels. Here’s How to Pick the Right Ones.
description: If you’re unsure about materials or you’re shopping online, there are some basic guidelines you can follow.
content: Bath towels may seem like a mundane entry on the checklist for your ideal bathroom, but there’s a science to choosing the right ones. A good bath towel should do several things at once — dry you off quickly, feel good (if not fantastic) on your skin, fit with your décor, and be durable enough to last for years. Different people find different towels comfortable, so the best way to find ones you like is to touch them (and even wash your favorites to find whether the feeling lasts).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Who Killed Sara?’ and the Art of the Netflixnovela
description: In the second season of the dizzying Mexican mystery-melodrama, the complications, and the suspects, just keep accumulating.
content: “Who Killed Sara?,” the popular Mexican mystery series that returns for a second season Friday on Netflix, is a little like an early-1970s Toyota Celica: an import offering an attractive package of sportiness and reliability. It overheats but it keeps moving. It and its excitable Spanish-language Netflix compatriots like “Money Heist” and “Elite” may not take over the American market the way Japanese automobiles once did, but cars have the advantage of no subtitles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Spectacle of the G.O.P.’s Shrinking Tent
description: Nicole Hemmer explains how right-wing media and minoritarian politics are shaping the G.O.P.
content: On May 12, House Republicans voted to remove Representative Liz Cheney, the third-ranking Republican in the House, from her leadership post. Her transgression? Vocally rebuking the claim that the 2020 election was stolen from Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Nottingham’s Dilemma: Robin Hood or High Tech?
description: An unlamented mall in the heart of the English city is being demolished. But what should go in its place?
content: NOTTINGHAM, England — Hilary Silvester still recalls the moment she first saw the Broadmarsh Center, a bleak 1970s shopping mall that symbolized Nottingham’s modernization in a scorned architectural era but is now being consigned to history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iyad Abuheweila, Adam Rasgon, Isabel Kershner and Marc Santora
title: Gaza War Deepens a Long-Running Humanitarian Crisis
description: The Palestinian enclave was already in a dire state. The war with Israel has made it worse, damaging the health and sewage systems, closing schools and displacing tens of thousands.
content: GAZA CITY — The nine-day battle between Hamas militants and the Israeli military has damaged 17 hospitals and clinics in Gaza, wrecked its only coronavirus test laboratory, sent fetid wastewater into its streets and broke water pipes serving at least 800,000 people, setting off a humanitarian crisis that is touching nearly every civilian in the crowded enclave of about two million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Are Americans Shopping Again? Macy’s Sales Jump Suggests a Return Is Afoot.
description: The retailer expressed optimism after sales soared 56 percent in the first quarter, raising its forecast for the year as consumers begin to buy apparel for get-togethers.
content: A combination of government stimulus and faster-than-expected vaccinations drove a sales rebound at Macy’s over the past three months, in what could signal the start of a post-pandemic shopping boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: CNN’s Zucker, Reunited With a Powerful Friend, Sees His Fortunes Change
description: Phone buddies and golf partners, Jeff Zucker and David Zaslav have a 30-year history. Now Zucker may be open to working for the man he calls a “best friend.”
content: Last summer, the future looked hazy for Jeff Zucker, the pugnacious president of CNN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Chris Hamby and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Troubled Vaccine Maker and Its Founder Gave $2 Million in Political Donations
description: Emergent BioSolutions faces scrutiny in Congress for ruining Covid-19 vaccines and securing lucrative federal contracts. Executives will appear before some lawmakers who benefited from the company’s spending.
content: WASHINGTON — When Fuad El-Hibri, founder and executive chairman of Emergent BioSolutions, appears Wednesday before a House subcommittee to explain how the company’s Baltimore plant ruined millions of doses of coronavirus vaccine, he will be questioned by lawmakers he and his employees spent tens of thousands of dollars helping to elect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Roger Federer Takes an Uncertain Step in His Comeback
description: Losing in his first match since March 11 to the 75th-ranked Pablo Andújar, Federer appeared fit but rusty. Most troubling was the fact that he admitted to lacking confidence.
content: The last time Roger Federer played in Geneva, 80,000 fans cheered him on at work over three days, filling the Palexpo Arena to the brim as he led Team Europe to victory in the Laver Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

title: You Say Plagiarism. I Say Provocation.
description: Sam Riviere’s novel, “Dead Souls,” considers fraudulence as a culture’s dominant mode of making art.
content: DEAD SOULSBy Sam Riviere

content: INSIDE MONEY
source.name: The New York Times

title: After Media Detour, AT&T Confronts Old Problems
description: Following its spinoff of WarnerMedia, AT&T is back to primarily being a wireless company, with all of the challenges that entails.
content: At a meeting of AT&T’s top leaders at the company’s headquarters in Dallas, Randall L. Stephenson, the chief executive, sounded a victory note. The wireless provider was on the verge of a transformative deal that would turn the phone company into a tech and media giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Masks and distrust.
content: The new mask rules from the C.D.C. amount to an honor system of sorts, where only unvaccinated people are expected to keep wearing masks in most places. But many Americans are wondering whether they can trust others to do the right thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peniel E. Joseph
title: Recasting ‘Riots’ as Black Rebellions
description: “America on Fire,” by the Yale University scholar Elizabeth Hinton, connects the unrest of the civil rights era to shifts in social policy authorizing aggressive police tactics whose destructive repercussions are evident today.
content: AMERICA ON FIREThe Untold History of Police Violence and Black Rebellion Since the 1960sBy Elizabeth Hinton
source.name: The New York Times

title: Did You Join a Protest for the First Time Last Year? Share Your Story
description: The protests that followed the killing of George Floyd were the largest in U.S. history. We want to hear from people who were moved to demonstrate for the first time.
content: We are approaching one year since the death of George Floyd at the hands of police set off the largest protest movement in U.S. history.

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Europe Calls for Immediate Cease-Fire in Israel-Palestinian Fighting
description: European Union foreign ministers, save Hungary’s, want the fighting to stop now and decry “unacceptable” civilian casualties in Gaza.
content: BRUSSELS — European Union foreign ministers overwhelmingly called for an immediate cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians in an emergency meeting on Tuesday, according to the bloc’s foreign policy chief, Josep Borrell Fontelles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Rami Nazzal
title: In Show of Unity, Palestinians Strike Across West Bank, Gaza and Israel
description: Hundreds of thousands stopped working for the day to protest their shared treatment by Israel. Many Palestinians described it as a rare showing of common cause.
content: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Hundreds of thousands of Palestinian citizens of Israel stopped work for the day on Tuesday, as did other Palestinians across the occupied West Bank and in Gaza, protesting violence against Arab Israelis, the unfolding Israeli military campaign targeting Hamas militants in Gaza and the looming eviction of several families from their homes in East Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These Invisible Whales Could Sink the Economy

content: Before he almost lost everything overnight, Bill Hwang was having a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Biden’s White House, staff members are not celebrities.

content: Mike Donilon is one of the most trusted presidential advisers in the Biden White House, but he comes and goes from his West Wing office almost as a spectral presence.

title: Is the Subway More Dangerous? Data Is Mixed, but Some Riders Are Scared.
description: City officials cite lower subway crime numbers, but a spate of random attacks has unnerved riders.
content: No one has to tell Raoul Rivas that the subway is more dangerous these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 2 South Carolina Deputies Are Fired for Their Role in Death of Black Man in Jail
description: The deputies, Sgt. Lindsay Fickett and Detention Deputy Brian Houle, used pepper spray and Tasers on Jamal Sutherland on Jan. 5 at the detention center in Charleston County.
content: Two sheriff’s deputies in South Carolina were fired on Monday for their role in the death of a Black man on whom they used pepper spray and Tasers after he was taken to jail from a mental health facility in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Val Demings is planning to challenge Marco Rubio for one of Florida’s Senate seats.
description: Representative Val B. Demings, a former police chief who represents a district in Orlando, had been weighing whether to run for Senate or for governor.
content: MIAMI — Representative Val B. Demings, Democrat of Florida, intends to run for the Senate next year,  two people with knowledge of her plans and the party’s strategy on Senate races said Tuesday. Her entry into the race gives Democrats a high-profile challenger against Senator Marco Rubio, the incumbent Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Nothing My Husband Did Helped’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: The closest thing my daughter, Ella, could get to a pandemic pet was a Venus flytrap (named Venus). Ella won a scholarship to boarding school and left last August. I lit candles for Venus and collected rainwater for her. Taking care of Ella’s fragile plant was as close as I could get to taking care of her. In the winter I thought Venus was dead. No, just dormant. I moved her to a cooler place and waited for spring. And then, a slender stem! A mouth and even teeth coming soon. Who said these girls are fragile? — Sharon Harrigan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Keep My Husband From Visiting India Amid Its Covid Surge?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing staying safe against traveling to care for family members abroad sickened by the coronavirus.
content: My husband and I have been married for a short time. We’re in our late 40s and are grateful to have found love; we have worked hard to understand each other deeply, especially because we were raised in different cultures: I in the United States; he in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Billy Witz
title: Stanford, Facing Pressure, Reverses Plan to Cut 11 Sports
description: The change of plans came within weeks of the teams potentially dissolving.
content: Ten months after revealing plans to cut nearly one-third of its varsity athletic programs, Stanford announced on Tuesday that those 11 sports would not be discontinued after all, ending a battle between the university and the supporters of those sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: What Is an Everyday Ballerina? A Luminous New Memoir Tells All.
description: For Gavin Larsen, the author of “Being a Ballerina,” the drama of a life spent in dance is the dancing. Period.
content: Gavin Larsen said she first felt like a writer in 2015 at an artists’ residency in New Mexico. She was there, not as a dancer, but to work on a book about her dancing career. And she was surrounded by musicians, writers and visual artists who didn’t know a thing about ballet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson and Ben Smith
title: WNYC Fires Bob Garfield, Co-Host of ‘On the Media’
description: New York Public Radio, which owns WNYC, said Mr. Garfield had violated its anti-bullying policy. Mr. Garfield said he had yelled and that “the provocation was extraordinary and simply shocking.”
content: Bob Garfield, a longtime co-host of WNYC’s popular program “On the Media,” has been fired after two separate investigations found he had violated an anti-bullying policy, New York Public Radio, which owns WNYC, said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan’s Yo-Yoing Economy Shrinks as Virus Spreads and Vaccinations Lag
description: The country has experienced cycles of growth and contraction in domestic consumption as the pandemic has waxed and waned.
content: Japan’s economy shrank in the first three months of 2021, continuing a swing between growth and contraction as its plodding vaccination campaign threatened to stall its recovery from the pandemic even as other major economies appeared primed for rapid growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Sarah Mervosh
title: The State Department reverses a policy that denied citizenship to some babies born abroad to same-sex parents.
description: The previous policy, which predated the Trump administration, required a child born abroad to have a biological connection to the American parent.
content: In a victory for same-sex couples, the State Department on Tuesday said it would grant U.S. citizenship to babies born abroad to married couples with at least one American parent — no matter which parent was biologically related to the child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: To reach climate goals, new oil and gas investment must be stopped, energy agency says.
description: The stark message is intended to address the gap between ambitious commitments on climate change and the reality that global emissions are rising, the agency’s leader said.
content: Investment in new oil and natural gas projects must stop from today, and sales of new gasoline- and diesel-powered vehicles must halt from 2035. These are some of the milestones that the International Energy Agency said Tuesday must be achieved for the global energy industry to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Claims From an Organized Crime Boss Rock Turkey’s Government
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, already hampered by an economic crisis and a surge in coronavirus cases, is now battling allegations of corruption in his ranks.
content: ISTANBUL — Sliding in opinion polls amid a severe economic crisis and a surge in coronavirus infections, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey is looking unusually embattled these days. And now his administration has been hit by a roiling corruption scandal that some say has a fin de siècle aura about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David S. Reynolds
title: Before the Civil War, America Was a ‘House Divided’ in More Ways Than One
description: Alan Taylor’s “American Republics” describes a nation that was less a united country than a congeries of feuding geographical entities.
content: AMERICAN REPUBLICS A Continental History of the United States, 1783-1850By Alan Taylor
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Dino Gaudio, a Longtime College Basketball Coach, Is Accused of Extorting Louisville
description: Gaudio was charged in federal court, where a filing signaled a plea agreement had been reached.
content: Dino Gaudio, who once led the men’s basketball programs at Army and Wake Forest, threatened to expose violations of N.C.A.A. rules at Louisville, where he spent several years as an assistant coach, unless the university paid him more than a year’s worth of salary, federal prosecutors said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Strange Moment for the U.S. Economy
description: Jobs are being left unfilled, used car prices are surging and the pandemic recovery is uneven. What’s happening?
content: It’s a weird moment for the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: My Father Was in a Coma for 57 Days. He Awoke to a Pandemic.
description: In this short film, the family of one of Spain’s earliest Covid-19 patients chronicles his battle.
content: In late February 2020, my father was admitted to a hospital outside Madrid with difficulty breathing. A day later, he was induced into a coma. He had no idea that he was one of the first people to be infected with the coronavirus in Spain. After 57 days of fighting for his life, he woke up with many questions about what happened to him and what our family had gone through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: A Rare Black-Owned Art Gallery Lands in Chelsea
description: After working with artists like Kehinde Wiley and advising collectors like Swizz Beatz, Nicola Vassell bucks the online trend with a brick-and-mortar space.
content: At a moment when equity and diversity have become paramount in the art world, Nicola Vassell, a former director of both the Pace and Deitch Projects galleries in Manhattan, on Thursday will open her own exhibition space on Tenth Avenue, planting her flag as a rare contemporary art gallery owned by a Black woman in the heart of Chelsea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael J. de la Merced
title: The deals that loaded AT&T with debt.
description: The decision to spin off WarnerMedia to Discovery ends an expensive deal-making binge for the giant telecom company.
content: AT&T is painting a rosy picture for the future of its media business, which it will spin off and merge with Discovery. That new streaming giant is a formidable stand-alone competitor to Netflix and Disney. The move leaves AT&T to focus on its telecom business, which looks less bright after being overshadowed by its expensive — and ultimately futile — deal-making binge in media and entertainment under its previous chief, Randall L. Stephenson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Why Can’t the Republican Party Quit Donald Trump?
description: The party’s base is in thrall to a leader who led it to defeat.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Teaching With ‘The Playlist’
description: In this column, music critics weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. We invite students to use it as a model for their own annotated playlists around a topic, theme or event.
content: Featured Column: “The Playlist”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Burleigh
title: Why So Many People Are Resisting Vaccination
description: Vaccines helped people overlook their vulnerabilities even as many of them became suspicious of the benefits of those shots.
content: Early in the 20th century, it was not uncommon for children to suffer the agonies of infectious diseases or witness family members who did. Children got terribly sick and died at home. Their survivors — including some of our grandparents and great-grandparents — were intimately acquainted with the sights, sounds and smells of dying and with the deaths of siblings or their own small children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Lee Goldstein
title: I’m a Trauma Surgeon in Israel. In My Hospital, We Are in This Together.
description: To me, this hospital — with its diverse staff and free medical care — represents everything that is beautiful and possible in this place.
content: HOLON, Israel — Late in the evening on Tuesday, I was working in my office in Wolfson Medical Center, the hospital where I am the director of trauma surgery. The sun had set and suddenly the sirens started blaring from every corner of Tel Aviv, warning of rockets headed our way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Georgetown’ Review: It’s Not a Lie if You Believe It
description: In Christoph Waltz’s film, a grifter takes Washington.
content: Christoph Waltz is a magnificent actor, and in “Georgetown,” as in everything, he is a pleasure to watch. As Ulrich Mott, a smooth-talking, uxorious grifter and social climber who wheedles his way into Washington society with the aid of his well-connected nonagenarian wife, Waltz flamboyantly charms and flatters, wearing a wolfish smile as he lies through his teeth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Euro 2020 Rosters: France Recalls Karim Benzema
description: France Coach Didier Deschamps called in Real Madrid’s Benzema for the first time since 2015. Rosters for the delayed European soccer championship are due June 1.
content: Real Madrid striker Karim Benzema was included in France’s preliminary roster for this summer’s European soccer championship on Tuesday, bringing to an end the six-year exile of a player who has been publicly critical of France’s coach, its players and its federation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Breyer Worries Retiring Could Add to Polarization. Would It?
description: The Supreme Court’s oldest justice has hinted that he may decline to step down, defying activists’ pressure. His reasoning would be hotly debated on the left.
content: When the Senate voted in 1994 to confirm Justice Stephen G. Breyer to the Supreme Court, the final tally was 87-9. Though he’d been nominated by President Bill Clinton, a wide majority of Republicans voted in his favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Weighs Investing $120 Billion in Science to Counter China
description: The legislation has drawn bipartisan support amid the coronavirus pandemic as Democrats and Republicans have become increasingly concerned about Beijing’s supply chain dominance.
content: WASHINGTON — An expansive bill that would pour $120 billion into jump-starting scientific innovation by strengthening research into cutting-edge technologies is barreling through the Senate, amid a rising sense of urgency in Congress to bolster the United States’ ability to compete with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Liz Cheney: The Model of a Modern Never-Trumper
description: The representative from Wyoming embodies a different kind of Republican female power player tradition.
content: In the six days since her defenestration from the leadership ranks of the Republican Party, Liz Cheney — the congresswoman from Wyoming, right-wing Republican, daughter of the former vice president and now leader of the anti-Trump party opposition — has been hard to ignore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Texas, Indiana and Oklahoma join states cutting off pandemic unemployment benefits.
description: The Republican-run states are joining a movement based on the contention that jobless pay is deterring people from seeking work.
content: Texas, Indiana and Oklahoma this week joined the growing number of states that are withdrawing from federal pandemic-related unemployment benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Workers at the Whitney Museum Move to Form a Union
description: Like other museums in the city, members of the Whitney staff are organizing with the United Auto Workers.

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: ‘Shrek’ at 20: How a Chaotic Project Became a Beloved Hit
description: Expectations were so low and the hurdles so plentiful that the crew wasn’t eager to work on the movie. Recasting after the death of Chris Farley added challenges, too.
content: The idea that an ugly ogre could be a big-screen hero in a romantic comedy-fairy tale was not one many had high hopes for. The lack of a traditional prince wasn’t the only hurdle for “Shrek,” the next big animated production from the newly formed DreamWorks. Producers and directors came and went. A major role had to be recast. And technology was proving to be thorny. In fact, the project was initially unpopular among employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Iran’s Oil Exports Rise as U.S. Looks to Rejoin Nuclear Accord
description: The effectiveness of U.S. sanctions is being called into question as Iran and its oil buyers test whether penalties are worth the risk amid diplomatic negotiations.
content: WASHINGTON — Iran is exporting hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil each day, violating American sanctions even as world powers negotiate to lift the economic penalties and revitalize a nuclear accord that was rendered all but defunct by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Stereotypes Are Rife Among Asian and Pacific Islander Film Roles, Study Finds
description: Two-thirds of characters reflect stereotypes, and just 3.4 percent of movies had leads or coleads who were Asians or Pacific Islanders, the study of 1,300 movies found.
content: Of the 1,300 top-grossing films released from 2007 through 2019, just 44 featured an Asian or Pacific Islander character in a leading role — and one-third of the roles went to a single actor, Dwayne Johnson, a study has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Catie Edmondson
title: Democrats, Growing More Skeptical of Israel, Pressure Biden
description: Among Democrats in Congress, attitudes toward Israel have grown more critical as the party base expresses concern about the human rights of Palestinians.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s carefully worded statement on Monday supporting a cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians came amid growing pressure within his own party for the United States to take a more skeptical stance toward one of its closest allies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spain Sends Troops to African Enclave After Migrant Crossings Jump
description: More than 8,000 people have crossed from Morocco to the Spanish enclave of Ceuta since Monday, creating a humanitarian emergency and deepening tensions between the two countries.
content: Spain deployed troops, military trucks and helicopters in its North African enclave of Ceuta on Tuesday after thousands of people crossed over from Morocco, one of the largest movements of migrants reported in the area in recent years.

title: ‘Broken Harts’ Review: Examining a Family Tragedy
description: This bland true-crime documentary tells the story of the Hart family, in which two mothers hid the neglect and abuse of their six children behind an idyllic facade.
content: The shallow documentary “Broken Harts” examines a tragic crime: In March, 2018, the Washington couple Jennifer and Sarah Hart killed their six adopted children by driving off a California cliff. At first, authorities assumed the car crash was an accident. Further investigation revealed that the women had been abusing their children, and had premeditated the plunge as an act of family annihilation.

title: A Michigan judge dismissed one of the last remaining lawsuits by Trump supporters challenging the 2020 election.

content: A Michigan state judge on Tuesday dismissed one of the last, high-profile court cases questioning the results of the 2020 presidential election, a case former President Donald J. Trump cited to claim fraud after unofficial results in one county initially assigned some votes for him to President Biden.

Perhaps that is, in part, why it has endured for two centuries. When it was built in 1823, as a residence for the branch of the Roosevelt family that would eventually produce Franklin Delano, it stood at the edge of the city, its north-facing facade looking out upon a mostly rural view. Within a few decades, though, the urban frontier had swept past it — the fancy people had moved on to Bond Street and Washington Square, and waves of immigrants crowded into the surrounding tenements. And so the house came to stand on a borderline between neighborhoods, its quoined corners and Dutch roofline attesting to its erstwhile respectability. It was the perfect choice for the two sisters who rented it in 1857.

title: OnlyFans Isn’t Just Porn ;)
description: Despite all assertions that the site isn’t powered by its sexual content, the platform is synonymous with porn. What is it really?
content: Gia the Smutty Mystic’s mornings resemble those of many people who work from home: She wakes up around 6 in her sunny apartment in the East Bay region of California and grabs her phone. Inevitably, there’s a backlog of messages from customers, most of which she responds to before she gets up to water her plants and wash her face. If it’s a Friday, when she usually records most of her weekly content — JOI (jerk-off instruction) videos are one of her current specialties — she has to work around the screams of children playing in a nearby park and traffic noise from the intersection outside her window. During the rest of the week, she’s seated at her desk by noon, editing, posting and queuing her content, which ranges from safe-for-work dancing videos to explicit boy-girl clips. Much of what she produces is shared on Instagram, Reddit and Twitter. But by 6 p.m., she’s “in the DMs,” meaning her private messages on OnlyFans, a subscription-based platform that allows people to charge for access to the materials they share. She’ll be there until midnight, sexting with customers one-on-one.

content: The Supreme Court decision in Plessy v. Ferguson, announced 125 years ago Tuesday, is duly remembered as one of the great abominations in legal history. By endorsing the notorious separate-but-equal doctrine, it consigned most African Americans to a state of rank oppression. In the space of no more than 5,000 words, it violated the plain language of the Constitution, engaged in expansive racist dissembling and defied the outcome of the Civil War.
